div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: RADICAL SLANDER.
div.p: We hope—though not with much confidence, for the misuhief makers sre tireless io their penitence—that the lost has been heard of the Natal ' atrocities" They prove* as might co: fidently have been foretold from the oatseh not to have been atrooities stall. and all tairminded Eugli-hmen will accept without hesitation the rfiidial statement of the Natal Government, which was read in the House of Commons yesterday by the Undersecretary for the Colouiee. But they will do do more than this. They will reprobate in the strongest manner the disingenuous attitude of the Ministry towards these slanderous attacks 01 the charaoter of their owo kith and kin. Instead of xialom-ly defending the honour of a little Colony ,which has been threatened with a terrible danger, the British Government has elected to play the part of a cold, self righteous judge. We deplore - the effeot. which the discussion that followed mnst have, upon all men of British blood ' in South' Africa, for what the Minister added, of his own initiates, cm only be understood as implying official esnsare upon the coidnot of one of tbeufficers ol the Natal forces. For the most sensational act of barbarism asoribed to the troops under the command of Colonel Mnokei zie was the foatting off of the head of the arch rebel Bambaata. The sugges tion was that this was done for sheer wantODness, as a piece of ferccions savagery, worthy of the dead man himself. We were old that the head was sent round as a'sort of ghastly trophy, to intimidate the other chiefs into sarrguder. Nothing coaid be farther, from the troth. The ofiioial explanation is perfectly simple and honoarable. Bitubasta's body at the bottom of a deep gorge, twothoasand feet below the oamp, and it was a matter of urgent importance that tbore t-bonld be no doubt as to his fate. Major Platt, of the Army Medical Corps, was sent with a native escort. He fonDd the body badly decomposed,and when the natives refaseid to cury it to camp, the head was ampnta'e I. it was kept under armedescort in absolate Privacy ; it was only shown to those whoprofessed to know the chief, and when the identity was verified beyond quee tion, it was retarnedto the spot where it htd been foand, and baried with the body. Wherein lies the atrooity What is there in this story which need inspire honor or disgust? T'hesnbjeot is an unpleasant one to dwell upon-like everyting connected with a postmortem—bnt there is absolutely not a shred of reaion why a British Minister should not have expressed his satisfaction that a fool slander had been so entirely disproved. That, however, is not the way of this Government iu dealing with the British Colonies. Their consistent attitude is to be willing to wound, yet afraid to strike. The Colonial Under S« cretaiy, when asked whether the Government had conveyed any comment on the the fcroatment'of Bambata's body, made the amazing statement that he feated "the British Govern-ment were not in the.best position to act" as oensors. And then he went on to say that under the late Administrationthe Khalifa's head had been "most shamefally treated and that he thought it obvious that "sneh. an evil precedent wooU be quoted against ns by the Colony in reply to any remonstrance we might think it necessary to make.* When Mr. Arnold Forster, very properly, pressed him to say whether he imputed any disgraceful aot fo Major Platt, the only answer he could obtain was that the Under Secretary for the-Colonies did not think it ' half so disgraceful as the steps taken in regard to the Mahdi." Frank and open oensore would have been far preferable to this glancing suggestion of condemnation, which. will be hotly resented in Natal. Moreover,the attack on Lord kitchene was. as gratuitous as it was unwarranted. There is no need dr us to justify what was done in the Sondan after the fall of Omdurman. On that oooasion, as in Natal, those in command of the troops took the measares they deemed . most efficacious for convincing tbsir beaten and fanatical enemies that further resistance was useless Then, as now, the sensation-mongers wereluiy with their lies. There were Exactly the same charges as to killing the wonnded. ft was boldly eaid that orders had been issued that no quarter should be given. Lord Kitchener was reviled by the tribe of unthinking sentimentalist! at horns, who hardly concealed their regrets that the British oasdal ties were so email in comparison with tbdsd of the Dervishes, and wrote of the Khalifa's savage tribe men as though they were entitled to the favour and consideration due to a civilised and hnmaue race.

Massacre there has efen none, though the ghastly mutilations perpetrated upon the few white men who have fallen into the hands pf these Zola rebels would go far to condone any savage reprisals committed in the heat o f action. It is difficult, however, to write with patience of the-atrocity loving public at home, for which these stories are manufactured with unfailing regdlAfity as often as war is afoot No charge is-too outrageoos to find credence,i f only it be brought against their own coontrymen. It is nothing to them if english officers are stoned and beafeo. to death by the rabble, of an Egyptian village, but their consciences are sorely hart if the morderers are panished. An English police inspector is stabbed through and through with assegais—it is a regrettable incident in the eyes of the English Radical. But when his slayers are tried by courtand fchot the Imperial Gjvernmoat must inter* vene. And if'the rebellion of a horde of bloodthirsty Zuffir, who would massacre! every man and woman in Natal if once they got the upper hand, is rathlessly crashed under foot by a gallant little band of white men fighting under conditions of great hazard and difficulty, a clamour rises for inquiry, and a Radical 1 Ministry looks on with cold suspicion is' ready with protestations of horror, and grossly attaoks the most distinguished ioidier in the aotfve service of the Crown. This Pharisaical attitude of mind is bound to have deplorable results in the Colonies. the slauders pnblisbed here so freely are all sent back over the wires, and read with anger. And the anger is just It is an intolerable thing that in this bard crisis of her fortunes so gallant, so loyal, so public spirited colony as Natal whose sons are fighting in the field, should be slandered n the Press of the Mother Coontry, and find, not friendship, but harsh censorship, in the Brititsh Ministry.
(From the "Daily Telegraph.")
The Brindisi Mail.
The mail for Europe, viâ Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Monday.
K. A. S.
The Society has decided to send Abde! Hamid Boy Abaza to Lower Egypt to teach modern agricultural methods to the fellaheen.
The Attack on a Soldier.
The assailants of Pte. O'Brien appear before the criminal Court on Sunday next. Me. Aly Bey. Assem has asked permission to defend the persons aconsed.
Riot at Deyrout.
Advices from Deyrout report that a serions riot took place there on the 20th inst. in the course of which twenty people, including 6 women, were wounded.
Railway Accident.
Another accident, this time on a small scale, is reported from the Matarieh line, where a goods truck ran off the rails on Thursday, causing some delay to traffic.
New Credit Opened.
The State Railway Administration has requested the Ministry of, Finance to open a credit of L.B. 24,000 for the purchasing of sundry material, and for minor expenses.
The Samama Affair.

The enquiry into the case of the young French protegé A. Samama whose sister was insulted and himself beaten by an Egyptian ex-officer is being carried on. We are glad to hear that the victim of the assault has stated that he has no complaint to make against the police.
Attempted Murder.

The news comes from Fashn that an onknown individual fired a charge of slugs on Wednesday evening into a party of Arabs who were seated in front of the house of the wekilomdeh. Four men were badly wounded, and the police enquiry has as yet brought no clue to light.
Alhambra Theatre.

To-night at 9.15. La Famiglia Pont- Biquet, by the Giovanni Novelli Company, comedy in 3 acts by A. Bessir. To-morrow at 4.30. p.m., matinée performance of La Zia di Carlo and Una Tazza di The. At night, 9.30, Kean, drama in 5 acts by A. Dumas, and Viaggio di Nozze, drama in 3 acts by G. Antona Taversi.
Criminal Shot.

News comes from Kom Hamada of the death of Bedr Hassanein, a local law-breaker, while engaged in pulling up the cotton of a certain Mohammed Abou el Ata, with whom he had long been on bad terms. A ghaffir coming up challenged Hassanein, who tried to show fight and was shot. Two other natives who were with him took to flight and escaped.
Publio Security in the Provinces.

Two days ago, Mr. P. W. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, and the mudir of Minieh, accompanied by the inspector of the Interior and the hukumdar of Minieh, proceeded to Fashn Markaz, where the state of public security has been very unsatisfactory of late. The anthorities have taken strict measures to preserve peace in the Markaz, and Abdalla Bey Mikhail, the retiring Omdeh of Fashn, has been re appointed Omdeh owing to his marked ability and the satisfactory services he has frequently rendered in the past.
New Employment Registry.

The British Chamber of Commerce, gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: THE NAVY ESTIMATES.
div.p: REDUCTIONS PROMISED.
UNIONIST DOUBTS.
LONDON, July 87..

HOUSE OF COMMONS-Mr. Edmund Robertson, Secretary to the Admiralty, said that it was the unanimous opinion of the Board of the Admiralty that the ship-building programme should be reduced as follows: 3 vessels of the Dreadnought type to be constructed instead of 4; 2 ocean-going destroyers instead of 5; 8. submarines instead of 12. By this means a saving of £2,500,000 would be affected.

Referting to the forthcoming Hague. Conference, he said that the Government, bearing in mind the resolution already passed in the House in favour of the reduction of armamente, proposed during 1907-8 to lay down two armoured cruisers instead of 4, with the provision that a third would be laid down if the Hague Conference was abortive.

This, he said, would be done in order to emphasize the good faith of the Government in the Conference, but it did not, however, exhaust the possible economies. The Lords of the Admiralty recommended reduction which they were unanimously of opinion would not imperil the balance of sea-power. Another faotor in favour of this reduction was, that that progress had not been made with foreign new programmes which the Admiralty anticipated when the estimates were framed a year ago.

Unionist speakers doubted whether the Lords of the Admiralty made the reductions of their own freewill and predicted that the Government's dream of international peace wes doomed to an early extinction.
Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman said that no one wished, the navy to be weaker but that extravagance does not secure efficiency. (R.)

div.head: INTERVIEW WITH M. STOLYPIN.
div.p: THE TSAR'S POLICY.
ST. PETERSBURG, July 27.

M. Stolypin, in the course of an interview granted to Renter's correspondent, stated that the Tsar has resolved to follow a policy of strong-handed reform. Nothing was further, he said, from his Majesty's wishes than the reaction which had occurred, but the revolutiomaries must be thwarted. M. Stolypin relied on the innate patriotism of the nation. He believed that the Tsar's appeal would result in the extinction or effective repression of anarchical forces. When the Cabinet was complete he would produce an exhaustive programme dealing with the land question. No steps would be taken against the members of the Duma unless they attempted to agitate. the country. The Tsar dissolved the Duma only with the utmost reluctance, when he found that nothing useful was to be expected from it.
(Reuter

div.head: MR. MACHELL'S DEPARTURE.
div.p: ABSURD RUMOURS.

A Cairo contemporary reported yesterday that Mr. Machell had indefinitely postponed his departure for England in consequence of orders which he had received from London. We. have made inquiries in official quarters in Cairo, and we are informed that this is quite untrue. The postponement of Mr. Machell's departure was decided upon by himself, and has no espe cial significance. The presumption, which our contemporary makes, that the postponement is due to the probability of further trouble is, we consider, not only unfounded but mischievous. It is exceedingly regrettable that a large portion of the Egyptian Press, both European and vernacular, is unable to maintain a calm and impartial tone, when exceptional and disturbing occurrences take place. The hysteria which is now prevalent in the Press is, of course, due to the Denishwai outrage and the strong measures which have been taken.. To assume from the proposed increase in the strength of the Army of Occupation that serious trouble is inevitable or even likely indicates, however, an unworthy timorousness. If the increase is effected, and we have every reason to believe that it will be, it must be regarded as a protective and demonstrative measure. We do not deny that there is unrest among. the Moslem population of Egypt, in fact we have ourselves remarked upon it, but even in the short space of time which has elapsed since the Danish wai incident greater moderation has been evident in the conversations of those who are wont to talk foudly in public places and, moreover, among those whose opinions are more sincere and who do not ta'k merely for the sake of causing agitation and gaining notoriety. We would be guilty of gross neglect of daty were we to disregard possibilities and scoff at patent indications of fanaticism or disaffection and we must therefore show, as we are now doing, that we are prepared to meet any emergency that night arise. It is an old adage that prevention is better than oure and at the present moment England by her foresight is taking care that no necessity for a care should arise. It is needless, we trust, to assure our readers that the rumours of a more general disturbance which are to be heard occasionally only emanate from the mouths or pens of the mischievons or thoughtless of whom there is a leaven in every country.
PLAGUE.
On Thursday & caso was admitted to hospital at Alexandria, and one at Mallaoui, while a recovery took pl cs at Suez. A native was found dead the same day near Lake Mallaha, Kism Karmons Markez.

Yesterday a youth from Tewfikieh kism Minet-el-Bassal was admitted to Alexandria hospital; and a youth from Port Said was found dead at Hadra kism in Moharrem Bey. He had come here a week ago from Ghirgheh, Sohag Mark In each case bubonic plague was diagnosed A further admittance to Suez hospital took place yesterday.
This mo ning the Quarantine Board reports the death of a seller of vegetables whose body was found in his house at Magarbe, Meshieh kism. Another case is reported from Mella wi.

div.head: ANTIQUES AT DAMASCUS
div.p: Advices from Damascus report that a great number of antiquities have been discovered by 'the workinen employed by the "Société Ottomane Anonyme des Tramways et Eclairage Electrique de Beyrouth." They are to be sent to the Stamboul Museum.

div.head: ENGLISH GRAMMAR FOR ARAB PUPILS.
div.p: We welcome the appearance of a new edi tion of the English Grammar for Arabic speaking pupils, and especially candidates.for the Primary certificate examination published two years ago by Mohamed Rakha and Mohammed Obeid, Professors at the Abdin School and Gordon College. The grammar is very clear and very thorough, and we notice a useful chapter on 'Common mistakes made by Egyptian papila. When will our Arabic grammars for English learners have a companion chapter or chapters on the mistakes we make ? Our congratulations to the authors on a very useful little work.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: The Grand Classical Concert with Orchestra piano and Harmoniom conducted by Maestro. Bracale will be held at ten o'clock to morrow. The programme includes the Grand Symphony of Saint-Saëns, which will be heard for the first time in Egypt.
In the afternoon Mr. Bracale will perform the Grand Overture of Wagner's Rienzi, as well as the trio from 'Laorezia Borgia' for soprano, tenor, and baritone. Entrance fee P.T. 5 per concert.

The S.S. Carib Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 27th inst, and due to arrive at Alexandria on Tuesday morning the 31st. Jaly.

div.head: REFUGEES IN EGYPT.
div.p: PERSECUTION OF RUSSIAN JEWS.

It is one in the natural order of things that the troublous times in Russia should have caused a large exodus of the persecuted Jewish population. The steamers from Odessa and other ports have for many months past brought refugee families to Egypt, and as the troubles are by no means over a large increase in the numbers in the near future is probable.

The destitution among these people who have had to flee for their lives is very great, efforts have been made in the past, and will be necessary in the future, in order to feed and clothe them and put them in the way of earning a living during the time they have perforce to remain in exile.

A few months ago a committee was formed under the presidency of M. d'Abaza, and we are. glad to record the measures taken accomplished, which has had the active co-operation of Mr. Rudolph, in whose home very many families have been fed and single men housed. Altogether about 150 families, have been assisted, 30 of which have returned to Russia. Many have been sent to Cairo, but much difficulty has been found in finding situations, owing to the men being unable to speak any other language bat Russian or Yiddish.

The committee have met twice a week, shoemakers, carpenters and others have been furnished with tools to carry on their trades, and monetary help has been given as far as the limited funds at the disposal of the committee permitted. Some of the mechanics are employed at the cotton spinning. factory and the rice mills at Karmous, and 26 are at work at Mariont, where an English Syndicate has purchased and is developing a large tract of land. The committee is assured that employment will be found there for many more but at present there is no accommodation tor then.

Fands being at the present time very low it has been decided to make an effort to increase them, and to appeal to the public to furnish the necessary means for carry on the work of relief. A largely attended meeting of the committee was held on Thursday last, 27 members being present, including the president, M. d'Abazi, M. von Back (Russian) vice-Consul), Baron Emile Menasce and Baron Menasce, MM. Mantachoff, Landauer, Hert- zenstein Margoliach, Radolph, and Danon (Secretary). It was decided to organise two fetes one at the Casino San Stefano, which will probably take the shape of a halland the other at the "French Garden," in the Place des Consul. The details are not yet settled, nor at the dates fixed but probably. the fêtes will be held on a Saturday and Sunday

A sub committee was appointed to make necessary arrangements. M. Landauer, manager of the San Stefano Casino, is cooperating in the scheme, which should met with hearty support from all, Jews, Christians, and Mohamedans alike. M, Rudolph, who, it is almost superfluous to say, is doing his utmost to help, speaks in the highest terms of praise of the efforts made by the Russian Consul General on behalf of his distressed countrymen, and the great sympathy shown by him. In a cause like this he should he well supported by all classes in Alexandria, and the coming fêtes secure abundant patronage,

The fête held on August 5 on behalf of the refugees, which will be under, the honorary presidency of M. d'Abeza, will be marked by a lottery the first prize in which will be a 51. H.P. motor car which won the Milan San- Remo race. Three 3% Crédit Foncier lottery bonds and three Panama lottery ticke's are also among the prizes.

div.head: DEATH OF CHIEF RABBI OF JERUSALEM.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.) Jerusalem, July 23.1

The death occurred on Saturday afternoon, the 21st instant, of the Very Reverend Jacob Saul Eliaschar, Chief Rabbi of Jerusalem and the whole of Palestine, at the advanced age of 93 years. The deceased dignitary held the Office of Chief Rabbi for nearly 14 years, previous to which he occupied for about 36 years the post of president of the Rabbinical Court, or "Beit-Eddin," in this City.

The late Chief Rabbi Eliaschar was very popular and enjoyed the fall confi'ence of his people, rich and poor alike, for his upright and sound judgement. He was esteemed by all classes of the population for his patriar- chal bearing and gentle manners.
His funeral was largely attended; nearly the whole Jewish population accompanied the Cortège to the Cemetery and as a mark of respect all the Jewish shops were closed during the funeral.

div.head: THE VATICAN BUILDINGS.
div.p: The "Stampa" maintains that its disclosures regarding the unsatisfactory condition of the Vatican buildings are absolutely correct. The apartments used by the Pops are especially in danger, because the supporting walls built in the Middle Ages in the lower part of the Vatican have been removed most carelessly. The Pope himself remarked recently to a foreign prelate whom he received in andience, "You see; I have no longer even a chapel, in which I oan keep the moat sacred things." The disolosures made by the "Stampa" ara felt to be accurate, for it was found necessary to carry out very tedious and complicated repairs in the Sistine Chapel in order to protect Michael Angelo's masterpiece from falling into decay, and the Papal gallery of pictures has had to be removed to other quarters for the same reason.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The report from Alexandria that the British garrison in Egypt is to be further increased and maintained so until the unrest has passed away has given much satisfaction in service ciroles. It is recognized that a firm policy is required just now, and it is considered a most providential thing that there are yet in the Liberal Administration Ministers who place the interests of the Empire before party. The 4th Battalion Rifle Brigade from Malta, and another battalion from Gibraltar are spoken of as additional forces for Egypt at an early date. It is expected that the 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards will be sent to Cairo.
Major D.K.E. Hall, commanding No. 2 Company Army Service Corps, Woolwich, has been noted for employment in Bgypt.

Rear Admiral George Le C. Egerton, C.B., has been appointed second in command of the Atlantic Fleet, in saccession to Rear-Admiral Sir A. Berkley Milne, Bart., C.V.O., whose tenure expires on the 25th August.

The cruiser Terrible, which is going out to the Far East with reliefs for the China Squadron, and the Australian Sqadron, will proceed by Cape Town, calling at Freetown en route, and will return home by the Suez route.

-The appointment of a combatant officer to the command of Military Mounted Police in Egypt will add to the status of that force, which consists of 120 of all ranks. Captain H. B. Protheroe-Smith, 21st Empress of India's Lancers, who has been appointed to the command of the squadron, is well known in Egypt, where he served, with the "Omdurman Boys,' and also on the staff, He served with honour under Kitchener in the Nile Expedition, in-. cluding the charge at Omdurman, the South African War, and in the Somaliland Campaign. of 1903-04.

The appointment of acting, adjutant to the squadron of Military Mounted Police in Egypt, has been given to Lieutenant Basil A. P. Schreiber, a subaltern of the 20th Hussars, presently stationed at Brighton. Mr. Schreiber served with the 20th in the operations in the Transvaal and Orange River Colony during the closing stages of the South African War (Queen's medal with four clasps) and is well known in Cairo, where he was stationed with the 20th.

Much indignation is expressed at the pitiful saving the Army Council will effect by the abolition of the appointment of seconds in command in the cavalry regiments and infantry battalions. It is pointed out that the post of second in command added dignity to the senior major's position, and its duties prepared him for the work of taking over command of a battalion, whilst the savings supposed to be effected in due course by the abolition of the appointment are so pitiful that they cannot be seriously taken into account.

Mr. Haldane has his work out out for him in connection with the proposed reduction of the Guards' Brigade by the abolition of the 3rd Battalions of the Coldstreamers and the Scots Guards. Already rumours of threatened resigns. tions by way of protest against any tampering with the Household troops are in the air, and it is well known that the House of Lords, those august fathers, uncles and other relatives of so many of the Guards' officers, will oppose any reduction of the Brigade. There is trouble ahead for Mr. Haldane in this matter.

Mejor W. F. Elmslie, Lancashire Fusiliers, has been selected for the appointment of second in command of the 2nd Battalion, Fermoy, and returns from the 3rd Battalion, Pretoria, to take up his duties. He is amongst the last of the cfficers who will be appointed "second in comman 1." Major Elmslie has served with the "Minden Boys" for twenty three years, reaching his present rank in 1900, and. he has the Nile Expedition, including the battle of Khar toum (medal, Egyptian medal with clasp), and the South African War, including the fighting for the relief of Ladysmith-he was badly wounded at Spion Kop-and the campaign generally, to his credit (mentioned in despatches, Queen's medal with four clasps)..

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: PLAY
CRICKET.
ALEXANDRIA. RAMLEH.

Played on Thursday and easily won by Alexandria. The town XI. won the toss and began badly, Cheeseman and Henley getting out in the first half-dozen overs. H. P. Carver and Marsden then made a long stand scoring freely all round the cricket. At 114 Carver was bowled for a freely hit 61 which included fourteen boundary hits and Macaulay and Marsden then added 35 more before the latter was caught at long slip by Cornish for a sound innings. McLean after being dropped off his first ball began to hit with great vigour usefully sup ported by Macaulay. One hundred and eleven runs were added before he was caught and bowled for a fine innings of 74 which included one six and thirteen fours. Foster hit a six before the innings was declared closed, Macaulay carrying his bat ton a freely hit 60 which included a six and nine boundary hits.
With the exception of W. E. Peel, who hit hard and well for 44, the Ramleh side fared badly before the bowling of Dawson and Maredep.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.H. Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha has left Paris for Interlaken, Switzerland, where he will spend the greater part of the summer season.
Mr. de Valdıôme,, Secretary of Legation, who is now acting French Diplomatic Agent and Consul. General in Egypt, has been promoted to the rank of Secretary of Embassy of the first class.
Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, Imperial High Commissioner in Egypt, has left Paris for Frankfort and Baden. His Excellency will return to Cairo in October next.
H. E. Harvey Pasha, Chief Inspector to the Ministry of the Interior, has left on a tour of inspection in Lower Egypt.

Advices from Constantinople report that Mgr. Photins, Orthodox Patriarch of Alexandria, is leaving shortly on an episcopal progress as far as Tripoli in Barbary, a journey which few of his predecessors accomplished owing. to the great distance.
Sir Nicholas O'Conor is leaving Constanti nople towards the middle of August en congé.
The Trade has been issued sanctioning the election of Mgr. Gregorius, Orthcdox Patriarch of Antioch.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST.
div.p: THE PROPOSED AMALGAMATION SCHEME REJECTED.

An extraordinary general meeting of the members of the Egyptian Land and General Trast, Limited, was held on the 19th July, 1906, at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, B.C.. Sir William Haynes Smith (the chairman) presiding.
The Secretary (Mr. W. T. Johns) read the notice convening the meeting.

It was moved and seconded that the meeting be adjourned for half an hour or three quarters of an hour, in view of the fact that a meeting of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, was called for the same time as the meeting of this company, and several shareholders of the trust were also interested in the Delta Company and wished to be present at the meeting. The motion, on being put to the meeting, was lost..

The Chairman; Gentlemen, in February las two directors of the Egyptian Dalta Land and Investment Company, Limited, one a member of their London board and one a member of their Egyptian board, acting entirely on their own initiative, proposed to us that our com- pany should amalgamate with their company on the basis of our giving five of our shares, on which 108. has been paid, for one of their fally- paid shares. The board of this company. care- fally considered the position and assets of both companies. They believed that the policy of amalgamation, if carried out on fair terms, had much to recommend it, because it tended to economy in administration and checked the constant competition between land companies, which was leading to inflation of prices. Your board accepted the offer thus spon taneously made to them, and on February 23rd a preliminary contract was signed in Egypt to carry out the arrangement. The London Delta board delayed their decision on the subject, and on April 7th we were informed that it was supposed that the Delta people in Egypt had been so busy with pur- chases and sales they have in hand that they had been unable to make an inspection of and report upon the Egyptian Land Com pany's properties. The Delta Land shares were at this time rising in price. At length, on April 30th, at a meeting of the two boards, the Delta London board finally declined to carry out the arrangement, on the ground that the rise of price in their shares made it useless to suggest the confirmation of the

contract Onr company .had during this pe riod held their hands as regards new bosj i oss, and were prejudiced by tho action taken. Considerable fueling was aroused among the shareholders in Egypt, and it is under stood that a member of the Delta London board was specially sent 'to Egypt in connec tion with the fasion of the companies. Ad vances were subseqaently again made to ns, and another preliminary agreement was en tered into on the basis of six. to one. This is the agreement now brought before tho general meeting. The shares to be given to XJS were to* be part of.tjieir authorised re serve of 50,000 shares. / After the second agreement WAS signed the board of this com pany ascertained that tha Delta Lands Lon don board had in their circular asking con formation of the second agreement also asked their shareholders ta inoreaae their oapital from £250,000 to £'>00,00% or, ip other words, to. double it'Their action appeared to m density affect the value of the ' shares they had agreed to give for our assets, and the scatter was, therefore, specially brought to the attention of our shareholders and of the Delta board. In their reply to our rem in strance the Delta board states:—(I) That only power to make sach increase WAS being sought; (9) that such increase was to bo made as and when and if required ; and (3) that the immediate issue of any part of it was so doab fill that the price of issue had not even been consiffere/,' and they farther stater! t|iat if tha occasion arore for issaiog, oar shareholders were likely to receive cmsiddrable benefit trom a pro rata distribution of new shares. The board of thia' company are advised by experts well acquainted with Egyptian business thd the mere decision to increase, the capital will be enough to start a selling movement, and that the proposals about the inore>se of capital prej idi oially atfectel the valne of the shares. It is clear that, if their oapital be increased as they propose, the holders ought to be prepared within the specifiel limits to find tin additional oapital wh ch tho Ddta bnrd may from time consider they neet To keep our shares equi valent to their valae any new issue would have to be at least over £ 1 10s per £ I share. D o our ahareho'ders desire to take up this possible liability which it is proposed should be brought into operation at the d:screti en of the Delta hoard? The reason why your board agreed to the first proposals for amalgamation was beeause th?y%el:eved the De'ta Linds had in past yea's purchased lands on exceptionally favourable terms—lands which had now become for aajle. Their shareholders had waited without dividends, while the shares to be given wero to rank with the original shares. Any increa a of capital certainly alters,the proportion held at the date of the last agreement of the shares then authorised to the existing assets, and it was on thie proportion your board based their consent to the arrangement. Again, is it probable thatnew capital can be emplo yed now by a land company in Egypt, in the face of the prevailing Competition, to the ffame advantage as when the Delta Lands purchased some years ago the Meadi Lands,which ^orm one of their principal assets ? Even if it is probable, do our shareholders desire to increase or double their investments'in Egypt ? The question whether the increase of oapital does or do not materially prejudice the valne of the share! to be given for oar assets is onewhich yon have to deoide for yourselves and, as our shareholders include many experienced men «rf basiu'essin Egypt, no doabt an accurate judgment will be given. Although the board are quite prepared, for the reasons before stated, to agree to' amalgamation on fair term", they are in no dernbt as to the success of yonr company. The assets are all good, aud are estimated, on a conservative basis, as being worth considerably more than the paid-np oapital, after paying all liabilities. While thes9 matters have been pending between the two companies two instalments of purchase money fjr lands became doe, -on June 30tb and Jaly 1st, and it was provided in the agreement that these should be paid in Egypt by the Delta Lands, they charging interest until it was decided whether the proposed amalgamation was to be approved. If the agreement is confirmed no point arises on this ; but if it is not confirmed the amonUt so disbnrsed will be returned, with the stipulated interest. There are no other liabilities of importance. The half rof the capital of the company which has 'Been called ap has been well employed, and the initial expenses of the company were less thin nsaaLfOne of our assets is tho interest of the company in the Shorbal Estate, at A'oxaodria. ft is a large bail ling estate, well situated and of ex ceptional and increasing valae, as being almost the only remaining laud available for building purposes within the quadrilateral area which forms Alexandria. The board declined an offer for this proparty, giving a profit of over £30,000 ; bat the company believe that con- si ferfbly largor profits can bo made if this property be olrafnlly realised. The resolutions are now snbmitted to the meeting.
Mr. J«- Robertson seconded t-h j resolutions.
Mr Wrightson asked if the oh'airman coold give the shareholders an 'approximate valuation of theNQomp iny's assets.
The Chairman said he estimated the value of the assets, after paying all the liabilities, at £130,0r0 net.
Mr. Cadman Jones moved the rejection of the proposals submitted because, in hisopinjor, the Delta Company had not. dealt in good faith.
Mr. Wrightson expreatei himsejf in fivoor of the rejection of the agreement. 4?

Mr. A. P. Mack said he wishe I, in fairness to the Delta Company, to state that when he WAS in Cairo at the end of May he met one of the directors of that company, who did mention that there was a probability of an increase of capital being made.
Mr. Howard asked if the shareholders might Ukalt that the directors as a body did not advise the carrying ont of the amalgamation.

Mr. Wrightson said it seemed to him that the assets showed a share valne of 13s. a share, and if they were to be 'given shares on the basis of 6 to Lthey ought to receive an exchange of approximately 78s.

Grookshauk Pasha said he wished to give a little note of warning to the shareholders. Certain things had arisen in Egypt lately wl/ch had con aid drab'y aHered the state of affairs there, and it was nopafc unlikely that they would see the market very low this winter.

The Chairman, replying to Mr,./Howard, said the directors had naturally endeavoured to obtain the opinion of those who were well arquaintod with Egyptian business with regard to the proposed anoalgamation. A member of a firm doing a large business in Cairo, Alexandria and London stated that the information from Cairo was that the idea of the Delta C jtupany's inorease of oapital was not welcomed by shareholders, and from Alexandria that the cironlar about the new issae had prodaced a bad impression among shareholders. Taking that view the agreement was one which the directors did not feel justified in pressing on the shareholders.
The resolutions were then pat to the meeting, and lost on a show of ban da by 3 votes to 11

div.head: EGYPTIAN delta LAND AND INVESTMENT cO., LTD.
AMALGAMATION PROPOSALS PROVISIONALLY AGREED TO.
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company Ltd., was held on the 19th July at Winchester House, Old Broad-street, E.C., Sir An k'and ^Colvin, K.C.S.I., K.C.M.G.,-C.I.E. (the Chairman of the company), presiding, f The Secretary (Mr. P. J. Horne) having read the notice convening the meeting,

The Chairman said - Yon will doubtle take as read the okonlar sent out by the Board explaining the ohjeots of this meeting. These objects comprise, as yon will have gathered— firstly, the acquisition by this company of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd , atid, secondly; alterations in the memorandum: and articles of association of our company. Owing to a difficulty which has arisen since the issce to yon-of the notice of this meeting in regard to the fusion of this company with the'Egyptian Land and General Toast, Ltd., it will he cotwe nient to pass first to the resolutions which are not affected thereby—namely, Nos 1, 2/3, 4. 5, 6/7, 8 apd 9. It is the case that resolution No.

V fur the extension of our sphere of operations, is partly due tp the proposed absorption of the Egyptian Land and General Trast, Ltd., bemuse no suoh restrictions as we are bound by SJ imposed upon that company. But we have every reason to believe that there are good opsoings for basiness in the Soudan and parts of Egypt from which we are now excluded by our memorandum and articles of association; and though, if the amalgamation referred to be not oarried through, the primary necessity for the alteration disappears, yet this extension of oar sphere , of operations most, before long, come, and the present would appear to be as good an opportunity as any. of dealing with it. Nos 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 8 are desirable alterations owing to the fact that the Delta Light Railways are no longer shareholders, and in consequenoa should no longer have control. In regard to No. 9 we regard it as a safe precaution to raise the minimum number of directors required to form a quorum at a Bjard meeting to two. Directors' Remuneration.

I now go back to No. 7 on the subject of the remuneration of the directors. The change in the directors' fees is,a matter which we wished in any case to put before yon. I must remind yoa that this company was originally regarded as likely to be a small affair, an cffihoot of the railways, and accordingly fees and salaries attached to it were fixed proportionately low. Bat it was farther provided that the directors should receive for division amongst themselves 5 per oent of the profits *in any one year after 5 per oent had been paid to th^shareholders.

It is. perhaps as well that oooasion has not yet arisen for such boons to ba claimed. An estimate of the accrued profits may be as safely calculated on. the present market price of oar shares as upon any other basis, and this means that as these profits are realised there will probably be considerables00*8 for division. Whatever might be the pecuniary advantages to the Board, they prefer proposing to the share- fhddera that the feei be fixed at what they believe a reasonable and equitable sum, whether as regards the shareh ddera. or directors. 'The fees are at present £IGO to the Chairman and £[() to each direotor, with the prospect of the boons referred to, which it is now proposed that they shoald definitely abandon. In my view, the proposed alterations which I have just enumerated are all desirab'e, whether the amalgamation with the Egyptian Land and General Trm-t, Ltd., is sanctioned oris not. shall be happy to answer any questiona in regard to them, so far as it is in my power, And I will proceed to the consideration of the remaining resolutions which depend opon such amalgamation. The general meeting of the Egyptian Land and General Trast. for the con sideratiOn of the fusion of their company with ,ours is fixed for the same time as the one we \re now holding, BO each is at the disadvantage of not knowing the views held or the decision arrived at or likely to be arrived at of the other. The negotiations in connection with the amalgamation commented in E/ypt so far back as February last, when certain diieotors of the two companies met in Egypt 1 need not enter

pon the earlier d.ffi mlties connected with these negotiation0, for they do not bear upon the point now at issue ; but it is neciseary foi roe to explaiu a difficulty created by Egyptian Land and General Trust since notices of this meeting were sent to you, andwhich may affect the whole position. To thirwd the secretary will read to-yoa the circular issued by the Egyptian Land and GeneraUrrnst, Lttfi, on the 6th July,' and our reply to(a jetterj/o the secretaries covering such circular dated
the 9 th idem.
The other Company's Circular.

The Secretary then read the following com mwioation-.—"Egyptian Land and General Trast, Ltd., 68 to 74, Palmerston hoaee, 34, Old Broad street, London, EC., 6th July, 1906. Dear Sir (or Madam),—Since the issue of the 4 last oiroqlar to our shareholders, dated 29th Jaue.recommeudirg the amalgamation with the Egyptian Delta Land and' Investment Company, Ltd., it has been ascertained that the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Ltd..- are asking their shareholders at their general ueeting, to be held op the .9th instant, crease their capital from £250,COO to £590,000 in other words, they propose to double their noteal capital. -The effect of this must b6 depredate the market value of the shares which the Egyptian Delta Land and Invest ment Company, Ltd., under the providonal agreement, w ire Ife give in payment for the assets of^ur company, and in fact, the market value of the shares in both companies has already considerably depreoiatel. Your .directors ^ava-Aot bien advised when or at whit price it is contemplated to make the new issue; but it is obvious that the apparent imminence so largo an isxue of new shate^mast prevent he value of tho snares hearing the proport'on which existed at the date of the provisional contraot to> the as-eta of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Ltd., already acquired. The basis on which your Board were originally propat ed to support the arrangement has thus been so materially altered that the Board can nrr longer *t ki the respons bility recommending the confirmation 6f the agreement It is imperative th$t the directors should1 know whether the proxioi already forwarded in response .to their first circular, or to sent in, are to he need for or against the confirmation of the proposed arrangement. Unless, therefore, you ^propose attending the meeting, will yon plAsse signify to ns your ieh in the course oj post £nd forward your proxy if not already Font.— By order of the Board, Mack and Palmer, Secretaries.''
The Chairman : A copy of the circular was handed to us, and we wrote as follows-—
The Company's Reply.

The Secretary (reading): * 9tl^July, 1906. Messrs. Mack and Palmer, Fecretaries, Egyptian Laud and General Trust, Ltd, 68 to .74, Palmerston House, E C. Dear Sirs,—I received with your assistant secretary's letter of the 6th instant oopies of circular - of the same date addressed to the proprietors of your company reference to the proposed- increase of this company's capital. My direotors cannot but regret tha*t they were not afforded an opportunity of eincidating this subject before the issue by your'oompany of a oiroular which may well cause an erroneous impression of their intentions. Iu this company's oircnlar of the 29th June it was briefly stated thet it was considered desirable to increase this company's capital to £*'00,000, but it was at any rate amalgamation, and the advantages or dis-advantages of any such /arrangement as an inorease of capital would he-shared all alike. Thei^nnmerical strength in shares would he as one to six of our present shareholders, and we might have reasouab'y expeoted them Ao feel safe in accepting the deoision of so large a majority, and of feeling assured that the Jhard of this-company would only exercise the powers conferred upon them in so far aif they belisve that the interests of the company and. therefore, of the shareholders of the Egyptian Land and General Trast, Ltd., would be ad- vancedlhereby.
The Chairman s Proposal. Lv The position being a

The position being as escribed to yoa, my proposal to you is that unless the shareholders of the Egyptian Land and General TrasMje found to have decided upon the amalgamation at their meeting now being hold, and on the terms arranged,such amalgamation be no longer considered by this company. If jfou are pleased to accept thia suggestion, I ask you to authorise me to aot in aocirdance therewith in reference to resolution No. 11, and I will now refer to the preceding resolution No. 10, whioh the only one remaining. Had it not been for the proposed amalgamation with the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd., we probably shoulduot have asked yoq * so soon to authorise ns to take power to increase our apital, and certainly should not have done so fpr so large an amount. I have explained to yon that no immediate fresh issue of capital

is contemplated, and under tbe^Jiresent conditions of doubt as to whether an amalgamation will or will not take place, I propose to postpone this question of an inorease to our capital until our next meetiog. In the event of an amalgamation the same inorease will be proposed to yon as in the resolntion which* we are considering, but otherwise power will be sought to provide for an addition of £100,000 only, in view of possible, though not probable,
known to Mr. Mack, one of yoar direotors, agencies in oar present sphere of operations,and

that paly power to make snoh inorease was being sought; f2) th* t each increase was to be made as and when and if required ; and (3) that the immediate issue of any part of it was so doubtful that the price of issue had not even been considered. The need for the provision for increasing this company's capital is created (l)hythefaot that the proposed acquisition of your company's a9iets will absorb the ba- lame at present available, and (2) by the proposed extension of its sphere of operation'. The authority now soaght is to provide for this possible want, and it appears to my di-rectors that, if it arises, your shareholders are likely to receivj considerable beuefit from pro rata distribution of new shares, and that as they will only form about one-seventh of the whole they may with confidence accept the decision arrived at bythe larger body—namely, our present shareholders—as to the necessity of making the provision proposed. I may ex plain that whatever inorease be made to this company's capital yoar shareholders and oars would be equally affeoted in every way. They farther understood from General Hallowes, a direotor of this company, who recently visited Cairo in connection with the fasion of our two companies, that the idea of increasing this company's capital WAS then mentioned in the presence of Messrs. Mack, Lonsdorfer, Nungo- vich Bey and othe-s. and was received by them-with favour.—Yours faithfully, (Signed} F. J. Horne, Secretary."

The Charman : I will now explain that the propo al for the acquisition of the Egyptian Land and General Trust necessarily, carried wifh it one ter power to increase this company's capital. Sach acquisition involved thepaymefit to theEgyptian Land and General Trast of 33,3'4 shares, and 4he advance »to them of £55,000 to meet their liabilities at the 30th June lastion certain lands, and would thus more than absorb the balance of our company's available capital. A a a consequence, and in view, of payments to become doe for properties acquired, and of the proposed extension of the sphere of our operations, we deemed it advisable totakepower to increaseonrcapital to£500,000. Beyond taking this power. I can unhesitatingly affirm that no programme as to ivsae immediate or otherwise had beeu conridered, and as to any date or price of issue of any of this fresh capita', 1 can only say that there details have never beeu fixed, and that the circular just read to you ascribes to us intentions which are fir bejond ns. Our intention, as the oiroular dearly expresses it, was simply to take power to issue capital at such futare time as, in oar opinion, might oall for a fresh issue. The power asked for of raising fresh capital and of a pro posal^ to raise fresh- oapital at an early date are absolutely distinct matters. As at present advised we do not propose to make an issne within the next twelve months, and before making any issue we intend to call a meeting of oar shareholders to lay before them the objects for which the issue is proposed, and take their viows as to the cxpendiency of the issue. The biggest issue we have ever made was £100,000, and it would be unreasonable to suppose that we contemplated issuing a quarter of a million, ithir at once or at any one time. 8uoh, how over, seems to have been the opinion created by the oircnlar in question, and on which the di-rectors of that company have withdrawn, as it Feems to os preoipitately, their recommendation to the Amalgamation of the two companies. Fiom what I have said, it follows that, as and when any fresh istue of our capital was to be made, the shareholders of the Egyptian Land and General Trust would got the benefit of such further issue or issue* equally with our present existing shareholders. The former gentlemen by having acqiffred fehare3 in our company would obtain thb right of subscribing for their proportion, or, bn to other hand, the shares were offered I th the public Ihey would get tin benefityof the proceeds there, The interests of tho /existing shaieholders of our compai y and of those of the Egyptian
Land and General Trast, Ltd., would be
tp avail ourselves of opportunities of bosiness in localities from which we have been hitherto exoladed, but which will now be opened to ns.
Mr. H. P. Singer asked if the Chairman coold give any information as to the reason why the Delta Light Rai'.ways had oeased to be shareholders in the company.

The Chairman replied that as long as the Railway Company were shareho'ders it was difficult for this company, with any chanoe of success, to apply to, the Con ft to obtain a modification of the memorandum of assoo:ation necessary to enlarge their sphere of operations. The Railway Company, therefore,' decided, under legal advice, to dispose of its holding, partly on that account, but also o^the ground that the company bad grown and changed into. much larger conoern than was originally designed. It was intended originally to parchsse land OD the line of railway in coarse con- 8traotion and to be constraoted, bat the'edm- pany had gone beyond this and the direotors of the railway came to the conolosion ^hat it was not stfiotly within their powers to be asso-ciated with the Land Company uoder its filtered conditions. They, therefore, decided to withdraw from their connection with the company. and sold their shares in it. The Railway Company had.certainly not in any way lost faith the concern, and had exhibited consideiabh^ objection-to onttiog the connection. f
Tho Resolutions.

The Chairman then proposed the following resolutions, which ware duly seconded by Major Li Breton and Major General Hallowes, and unanimously agreed to, namely :—That the memorandum and artic'.es'of association be varied as follows (1) By striking out from section 3, sub-section (a) of the memoranda m of association the words "in any distriot" and by snbstitnti'pg for the words "in which the railways bilongingto or that may at any time hereaf.er belong to the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd.,* or any extension or branch thereof existing or hereafter constrnoted or proposed to be constrnoted, may serve or be intended to serve" occurring in Jhe same* subsection the words "or in thefcadan." (2) That artiole 75 of the artides of Association of the company be altered by striking oot the words commencing ''and every exercise of the power" down to the end of that article. (3) That article 81 be altejed by striking out the words "or a person to be nominated as hereinafter provided by the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited." (4) That article 85 be altered by striking out the wordi "provided that this prohibition tehall not apply to any contract dealing or transaction with the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd." (5) That artiole 86 be ajtered by striking oat all words after the words "shall be vaoant" (6) That artiole 87 be altered by.striking ont the words "eave as aforesaid" appearing in the first line of sheb article. (7) That artiole 89. be strode ont and that there be substituted therefor the follow ing article: "The remuneration of the direotors shall' be the sum of £250 per annnm to each of the direotors and £500 per annnm to the Chairman, and such remuneration shall.be deemed to accrue do die in diem. The remuneration shall be exclusive of the sums, if any, which under the provisions of these presents the Board may agree to pay to Any managing director or to any director on aooonnt of special services." (8) That article 90 be altered by striking out the words "provided he be approved by the Board of the Egyptian Delta Light Railwayp, Ltd." (9) That article 96 be altered by striking ont the words "one direotor" and snbstitutiug therefor the words "two directors." Capital Resolution Withdrawn.
Tho Chairman stated that resolntion No. 10

"That the capital of the company be increased from £250,000 to £590,00 »"—was withdrawn. He added: Toia will be left over to be dealt with at the uext meeting, which will be field in about four weeks' tim*. If the amalgamation scheme with the Bgyptian Land and General Trust goes through at that meeting, identical in from the time of the then he increase to £509,000 will be proposed.
He is thus brought to see a great npany of such cases every year, the moat of whom return to their homes to complete their treatment by correspondence. .' ,
Those wishing to become by correspondence shofilTaddn Hartman, President bf the Hartman\ Sanitarium Columbus, Ohio.

If on the other hand, it does not go through, an inorease of an additional £106,000 only will be pot forward. I qext propose to not resolution No. 11, with>a small modification inserted. Thia modification is to the effect that the agreement is approved, snbj ot to its being to-day approved at the meeting of the Trast Company. Resolution No. 11 will read as follows"That the memorandam of agreement between the company and the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd. now submitted to the meeting, and initialled by the Chairman for the purpose of identification, be ap- proved and authorised to ba entered into, sab- jeot"—aod these are the new words—' to the 8a:d memorandum of agreement being approved this 19th of July by the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd., in general meeting assembled,and"—here end the words inserted—' sub- jeot to snoh alterations, as the Board may think fi»; and tint the Board basaukhorised to enter into snoh further or other agreements as they may thick desirable for carrying such memo-randum of agreement into eftect."
Major Le Breton seconded- the motion, which was carried unanimously.

Mr. Singer : Before we clow the meeting 1 think we should thank our Chairman for the oare he has taken of the company, and also for presiding to-day. We all appreciate the services he has rendered to the company in the past, and 1 am snre we oan leave the matter of the amalgamation and the fntnre issue of capital safely in his hands and those of the other members of the Board. (Applause.)
Mr. W. Baker seconded the motion, whioh was very condially received.

The Chairman : On behalf of the directors and myself let me thank yon for the expression of confidence yoU have placed in us. Let me also add that I trust the result of our enterprise will moet all your reasonable wishes. Yon may rely upon it that no efforts shall be spared on our part to show that the confidence yon have reposed in os has not been misplacei. (Applause.)
The meeting then separated.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

Dr. Le Clerc's

div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional).
